articles.headline: When Your 401(k) Is Better for Your Employer
articles.snippet: Some companies are using legal tactics to shield themselves from litigation over issues like fees and plan choices, sometimes at members’ expense.
articles.abstract: Some companies are using legal tactics to shield themselves from litigation over issues like fees and plan choices, sometimes at members’ expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is your retirement plan set up to benefit you, or your employer?

articles.headline: A Suburban Experiment Aims for Free Energy
articles.snippet: Twenty homes in a California subdivision are testing a zero net energy goal: to make at least as much energy as they use over a year.
articles.abstract: Twenty homes in a California subdivision are testing a zero net energy goal: to make at least as much energy as they use over a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: FONTANA, Calif. — At first glance, Anthony and Vanessa Genau’s home in a subdivision beneath the San Gabriel Mountains here is like any other gracious new suburban dwelling, with an open-plan living space, granite countertops and stainless steel appliances.

articles.headline: Tony Fadell Steps Down Amid Tumult at Nest, a Google Acquisition
articles.snippet: Mr. Fadell, a star executive known for his aggressive management style, helped found the maker of high-tech home devices and sold it to Google for $3.2 billion 2014.
articles.abstract: Mr. Fadell, a star executive known for his aggressive management style, helped found the maker of high-tech home devices and sold it to Google for $3.2 billion 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time to move on. That is the explanation Tony Fadell, a former star executive at Apple known for his aggressive management style, offers for his departure from Nest, a maker of digital versions of household staples like thermostats and smoke detectors that he helped found and sold to Google.

articles.headline: Walmart Worker Advocates Express Skepticism Over Raises
articles.snippet: Employees more critical of the company say it has found subtle ways to hinder workers’ compensation, such as a training program that can keep pay at $9 an hour.
articles.abstract: Employees more critical of the company say it has found subtle ways to hinder workers’ compensation, such as a training program that can keep pay at $9 an hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — This week, as part of the festivities that surround Walmart’s annual shareholder meeting, “Eye of the Tiger” blasted through loudspeakers as employees entered an arena at the University of Arkansas. Handpicked by their managers out of Walmart’s work force of more than a million, the employees arrived ready to cheer.

articles.headline: For Driverless Cars, Citylike Test Sites Offer the Unpredictable
articles.snippet: Testing is being conducted at controlled, secretive locations like Mcity in Michigan because the number of unforeseen challenges on the road is almost limitless.
articles.abstract: Testing is being conducted at controlled, secretive locations like Mcity in Michigan because the number of unforeseen challenges on the road is almost limitless.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Here in this college town 40 miles west of Detroit, behind black sheeting attached to an eight-foot-tall chain-link fence, the future of the auto industry is being worked out in a secret setting.

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Boss Faces Revolt From Bankers Over Strategy Shift
articles.snippet: A drop in bonuses and a move away from investment banking have led traders to grumble about Tidjane Thiam’s plans for the future of the Swiss bank.
articles.abstract: A drop in bonuses and a move away from investment banking have led traders to grumble about Tidjane Thiam’s plans for the future of the Swiss bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Tidjane Thiam took over at Credit Suisse last July, he laid out a new direction for a financial giant with a storied investment banking history: Do less investment banking.

articles.headline: Once a Trump Target, John McCain Now Finds Their Political Fates Intertwined
articles.snippet: The senator says he’ll back his party’s presumptive nominee. But with his own seat on the line and Arizona Hispanics at odds with Donald Trump, it’s a risky position.
articles.abstract: The senator says he’ll back his party’s presumptive nominee. But with his own seat on the line and Arizona Hispanics at odds with Donald Trump, it’s a risky position.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — Senator John McCain does not say much these days about Donald J. Trump’s attack on his five-plus years as a prisoner of war. Instead, he clenches his teeth and says he will support the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee, who once said derisively about the senator’s time in captivity, “I like people that weren’t captured.”

articles.headline: Iraqi Army Seen as Ill Equipped to Retake Mosul From ISIS, Despite U.S. Aid
articles.snippet: The Iraqis are having trouble moving supplies to their troops on battlefields, and a planned offensive against the Islamic State’s stronghold will probably have to wait.
articles.abstract: The Iraqis are having trouble moving supplies to their troops on battlefields, and a planned offensive against the Islamic State’s stronghold will probably have to wait.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An exhausted and ill-equipped Iraqi Army faces daunting obstacles on the battlefield that will most likely delay for months a long-planned major offensive on the Islamic State stronghold of Mosul, American and allied officials say.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Could a Muslim Judge Be Neutral to Donald Trump? He Doesn’t Think So
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s remarks came amid growing disapproval from fellow Republicans over his attacks on a federal judge overseeing a suit against the defunct Trump University.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s remarks came amid growing disapproval from fellow Republicans over his attacks on a federal judge overseeing a suit against the defunct Trump University.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who said last week that a judge’s Mexican heritage should disqualify him from a lawsuit against Mr. Trump, expressed doubt on Sunday that a Muslim judge could remain neutral in the case, comments that are unlikely to ease concerns among his fellow Republicans who fear his controversial remarks could hurt the party in November.

articles.headline: Panama Papers Show How Rich United States Clients Hid Millions Abroad
articles.snippet: Mossack Fonseca, the Panamanian law firm at the center of the trove of revealing documents, offered a menu of services to conceal the true owners.
articles.abstract: Mossack Fonseca, the Panamanian law firm at the center of the trove of revealing documents, offered a menu of services to conceal the true owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, William R. Ponsoldt had earned tens of millions of dollars building a string of successful companies. He had renovated apartment buildings in the New York City area. Bred Arabian horses. Run a yacht club in the Bahamas, a rock quarry in Michigan, an auto-parts company in Canada, even a multibillion-dollar hedge fund.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: U.S. to Press China to Curb Industrial Output
articles.snippet: “Excess capacity is not just a domestic issue,” Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew said ahead of the two nations’ Strategic and Economic Dialogue.
articles.abstract: “Excess capacity is not just a domestic issue,” Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew said ahead of the two nations’ Strategic and Economic Dialogue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Obama administration plans to use annual talks with leaders in Beijing to push for cuts in excess Chinese industrial output, which has inundated foreign markets with discounted steel, aluminum and other products, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said in Beijing on Sunday ahead of the meeting.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Watchdog That Shepherded Panama Papers Now Constrained by Finances
articles.snippet: Financial woes have forced cutbacks at the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, even as the effects of the Panama Papers have raised its profile.
articles.abstract: Financial woes have forced cutbacks at the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, even as the effects of the Panama Papers have raised its profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As news outlets round the world continued to publish revelations from the Panama Papers, the nonprofit organization that coordinated the project was preparing to move out of its offices here in an effort to cut costs.

articles.headline: A Carnival of Life Flourishes in Kabul’s Field of the Dead
articles.snippet: At the Kart-e-Sakhi cemetery, children hustle for tips, young lovers seek privacy, a cotton-candy seller circulates and cockfights are held every weekend.
articles.abstract: At the Kart-e-Sakhi cemetery, children hustle for tips, young lovers seek privacy, a cotton-candy seller circulates and cockfights are held every weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The children’s gathering point is the grave of one Bibi Jawaher. She has been dead for 27 years, the inscription on her headstone so faded that you have to run your fingers over it to fully make out her name and the year of her death.

articles.headline: Smaller Chips May Depend on Vacuum Tube Technology
articles.snippet: The vacuum tube, a 100-year-old technology replaced by transistors, could make a comeback as a way to shrink computer chips beyond the limits of silicon.
articles.abstract: The vacuum tube, a 100-year-old technology replaced by transistors, could make a comeback as a way to shrink computer chips beyond the limits of silicon.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — The future of computing may be in its past.

articles.headline: Led Zeppelin’s ‘Stairway to Heaven’ to Be Scrutinized in Court in Copyright Case
articles.snippet: This case — in which a lawsuit claims that part of the classic hit was copied from “Taurus,” a tune by Spirit — is being watched as a test of the limits of copyright.
articles.abstract: This case — in which a lawsuit claims that part of the classic hit was copied from “Taurus,” a tune by Spirit — is being watched as a test of the limits of copyright.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beyoncé is on tour, Drake is setting streaming records and Taylor Swift has split up with her boyfriend. But next week, the most gripping news for the music industry may come out of a federal courtroom in Los Angeles.

articles.headline: The Trump Show, a Hit for Now, Faces a Test in the Fall
articles.snippet: The Donald Trump media operation, which has dominated the political conversation so far, faces a bigger challenge in the general election.
articles.abstract: The Donald Trump media operation, which has dominated the political conversation so far, faces a bigger challenge in the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time to stop calling Donald J. Trump’s presidential operation “the Trump campaign.” It would be far more accurate to call it “Trump Productions Inc.”

articles.headline: Why the Economic Payoff From Technology Is So Elusive
articles.snippet: Areas like computing and mobile devices have made advances, but the government has reported disappointingly slow growth and continuing stagnation in productivity.
articles.abstract: Areas like computing and mobile devices have made advances, but the government has reported disappointingly slow growth and continuing stagnation in productivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Your smartphone allows you to get almost instantaneous answers to the most obscure questions. It also allows you to waste hours scrolling through Facebook or looking for the latest deals on Amazon.

articles.headline: In Mississippi Town, Some Fear School Desegregation Ruling May Backfire
articles.snippet: Cleveland wonders whether it should fight to maintain the modicum of integration it has achieved, or accept the federal government’s more vigorous efforts to desegregate.
articles.abstract: Cleveland wonders whether it should fight to maintain the modicum of integration it has achieved, or accept the federal government’s more vigorous efforts to desegregate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Miss. — The multicultural high school band kicked off a punchy “Pomp and Circumstance” as the 2016 graduates of Cleveland High School marched across the gymnasium. They were a near-equal mix of black and white students, with the occasional Nguyen, Patel or Rojas sprinkled among them.
